questions.question: [Problem] For M20 grade concrete, what is the value of the modular ratio 'm' as per the formula $m = \frac{280}{3\sigma_{cbc}}$?

[Problem] A singly reinforced rectangular beam has an effective depth of 500 mm. If M20 concrete and Fe415 steel are used, what is the depth of the critical neutral axis ($x_c$)? (Use m=13.33, $\sigma_{st}=230$ MPa)

answerOptions.text: 200 mm
144 mm
245 mm
188 mm

questions.question: [Problem] For a balanced rectangular section using M20 concrete and Fe415 steel, what is the lever arm factor 'j'? (Use neutral axis factor k=0.288)

[Problem] Calculate the moment of resistance of a balanced rectangular section with width b=300 mm and effective depth d=500 mm, using M25 concrete ($\sigma_{cbc}=8.5$ MPa) and Fe250 steel ($\sigma_{st}=140$ MPa).

answerOptions.text: 95.2 kNm
88.4 kNm

questions.question: [Problem] A beam with b=250mm, d=400mm, $A_{st}$=1256 mm², M20 concrete, and Fe415 steel has an actual neutral axis depth of 175 mm and a critical neutral axis depth of 115 mm. How would you classify this section?

answerOptions.text: Under-reinforced
Balanced
Over-reinforced
Insufficient data

questions.question: [Problem] A simply supported beam is subjected to a service moment of 100 kNm. If the section is 300mm wide with an effective depth of 500mm, what is the required area of Fe415 steel ($\sigma_{st}=230$ MPa)? Assume a lever arm factor j=0.904.

answerOptions.text: 1255 mm²
962 mm²
1100 mm²
850 mm²

questions.question: [Problem] According to IS 456, what is the permissible tensile stress ($\sigma_{st}$) for an Fe415 grade steel bar with a diameter of 25 mm?

answerOptions.text: 140 MPa
190 MPa
230 MPa
250 MPa

questions.question: [Hard Theory] How does the phenomenon of creep in concrete affect the stresses in steel and concrete over the long term under sustained loads in WSM?

answerOptions.text: It increases the stress in concrete and decreases the stress in steel.
It decreases stresses in both materials due to stress relaxation.
It increases the effective modular ratio, causing a transfer of compressive stress from concrete to steel.
It has no effect on stress distribution, only on overall deflection.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] WSM is considered unsuitable for ultimate load design because its 'Factor of Safety' is notional. Why is the true margin of safety against collapse unknown in this method?

answerOptions.text: Because it neglects the tensile strength of concrete.
Because it doesn't account for the non-linear, plastic behavior of materials near their failure state.
Because the assumed value of Young's Modulus for concrete is often inaccurate.
Because it applies the factor of safety to stresses instead of loads.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] In the WSM analysis of a T-beam, what is the primary implication if the calculated neutral axis depth 'x' is found to be greater than the flange depth '$D_f$?'

answerOptions.text: The section must be redesigned with a thicker flange.
The beam will behave as a rectangular beam of width equal to the web width '$b_w$'.
The analysis must consider the flanged shape, and the compression force is calculated in two parts (flange and web).
The beam is inherently unsafe and will fail in compression.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] The permissible stress in bending compression ($\sigma_{cbc}$) is higher than in direct compression ($\sigma_{cc}$). This is justified by stress redistribution. Why is this justification somewhat contradictory to the core assumptions of WSM?

answerOptions.text: Because WSM assumes steel carries all the tension.
Because stress redistribution is a phenomenon of plastic, non-linear behavior, whereas WSM assumes purely linear-elastic behavior.
Because the modular ratio already accounts for all stress variations.
Because bending loads are inherently less critical than axial loads.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] Why is WSM still sometimes preferred for designing structures like water tanks, despite being largely superseded by LSM?

answerOptions.text: Because it results in thinner, more economical sections for such structures.
Because the calculations are simpler and faster for liquid loads.
Because its focus on limiting stresses at service loads provides better control over cracking, a key serviceability concern.
Because LSM cannot be applied to structures subjected to hydrostatic pressure.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] A major conceptual flaw of WSM is its handling of different load types. Which statement best describes this limitation?

answerOptions.text: It cannot handle dynamic loads like earthquakes.
It applies the same factor of safety to loads of different variability, such as highly predictable Dead Loads and uncertain Live Loads.
It requires separate and complex calculations for each load combination.
It systematically overestimates the magnitude of all applied loads.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] What is the primary role of adding compression reinforcement in a doubly reinforced beam designed using WSM, beyond simply increasing its moment of resistance?

answerOptions.text: To reduce the long-term deflection due to creep and shrinkage.
To ensure the section fails in a brittle compression failure mode.
To decrease the depth of the neutral axis, thus making the section more brittle.
To eliminate the need for shear reinforcement.

questions.question: [Hard Theory] If the cost of steel is unusually high relative to concrete, which WSM design approach might be more 'economical' in terms of total cost, contrary to conventional wisdom?

answerOptions.text: An under-reinforced section, as it uses a lower percentage of steel.
An over-reinforced section, as it maximizes the use of cheaper concrete.
A balanced section, as it is always the most efficient use of both materials.
A doubly reinforced section, as it minimizes the overall depth.
